psef package¶

Module contents¶

psef.LTI_ROLE_LOOKUPS = {‘learner’: {‘course_role’: True, ‘role’: ‘Student’}, ‘teachingassistant’: {‘course_role’: True, ‘role’: ‘TA’}, ‘instructor’: {‘course_role’: True, ‘role’: ‘Teacher’}, ‘administrator’: {‘course_role’: False, ‘role’: ‘Admin’}}¶

A LTI role to psef role lookup dictionary.

Note

The roles are both course and user roles.

psef.create_app(config=None)[source]¶
psef.not_found(error)[source]¶
psef.set_request_start_time()[source]¶

Submodules¶

psef.auth module¶

This module implements all authorization functions used by psef.

exception psef.auth.PermissionException(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: psef.errors.APIException

The exception used when a permission check fails.

class psef.auth.RequestValidatorMixin[source]¶

Bases: object

A ‘mixin’ for OAuth request validation.

is_valid_request(request, parameters={}, fake_method=None, handle_error=True)[source]¶
Validates an OAuth request using the python-oauth2 library:
https://github.com/simplegeo/python-oauth2
parse_request(request, parameters, fake_method)[source]¶

This must be implemented for the framework you’re using Returns a tuple: (method, url, headers, parameters) method is the HTTP method: (GET, POST) url is the full absolute URL of the request headers is a dictionary of any headers sent in the request parameters are the parameters sent from the LMS

Parameters:
  • request (object) – The request to be parsed.
  • parameters (dict) – Extra parameters for the given request.
  • fake_method (object) – The fake method to be used.
Return type:

tuple[str, str, dict[str, str], dict[str, str]]
Returns:

A tuple of, respectively, the requets method, url, headers and form, where the last two are a key value mapping.
valid_request(request)[source]¶

Check whether the OAuth-signed request is valid and throw error if not.

psef.auth.ensure_can_see_grade(work)[source]¶

Ensure the current user can see the grade of the given work.

Parameters:

work (models.Work) – The work
Returns:

Nothing
Return type:

None
Raises:
  • PermissionException – If there is no logged in user. (NOT_LOGGED_IN)
  • PermissionException – If the user can not see the grade. (INCORRECT_PERMISSION)

Ensure the current user is enrolled in the given course.

Parameters:

course_id (int) – The course id of the course.
Returns:

Nothing
Return type:

None
Raises:
  • PermissionException – If there is no logged in user. (NOT_LOGGED_IN)
  • PermissionException – If the user is not enrolled in the given course. (INCORRECT_PERMISSION)
psef.auth.ensure_permission(permission_name, course_id=None)[source]¶

Ensure that the current user is logged and has the given permission.

Parameters:
  • permission_name (str) – The name of the permission to check for.
  • course_id (None or int) – The course id of the course that should be used for the course permission, if it is None a role permission is implied. If a course_id is supplied but the given permission is not a course permission (but a role permission) this function will NEVER grant the permission.
Returns:

Nothing
Return type:

None
Raises:
  • PermissionException – If there is no logged in user. (NOT_LOGGED_IN)
  • PermissionException – If the permission is not enabled for the current user. (INCORRECT_PERMISSION)
psef.auth.ensure_valid_oauth(key, secret, request, parser_cls=<class ‘psef.auth._FlaskOAuthValidator’>)[source]¶

Make sure the given oauth key and secret is valid for the given request.

Parameters:
  • key (str) – The oauth key to be used for validating.
  • secret (str) – The oauth secret to be used for validating.
  • request (object) – The request that should be validated.
  • parser_cls (RequestValidatorMixin) – The class used to parse the given request it should subclass RequestValidatorMixin and should at least override the RequestValidatorMixin.parse_request() method.

Ensure that the current user is logged and has the given permission.

Parameters:

  • course_id (None or int) – The course id of the course that should be used for the course permission, if it is None a role permission is implied. If a course_id is supplied but the given permission is not a course permission (but a role permission) this function will NEVER grant the permission.

Nothing
Return type:

psef.blackboard module¶

This module implements the parsing of blackboard gradebook info files.

psef.blackboard.FileInfo¶

A namedtuple holding information about a specific file.

psef.blackboard.original_name¶
The name provided by the user
psef.blackboard.name¶
The name as stored in the blackboard gradebook

alias of SubmissionFileInfo

psef.blackboard.Info¶

A namedtuple holding information about a specific file

psef.blackboard.student_name¶
The name of the student
psef.blackboard.student_id¶
The id of the student in the system of the university
psef.blackboard.assignment_name¶
Name of the assignment
psef.blackboard.created_at¶
The datetime when the submission was made
psef.blackboard.grade¶
The current grade of the submission
psef.blackboard.text¶
The html text submission of the student
psef.blackboard.comment¶
Comment included by student
psef.blackboard.files¶
The files submitted by the user as list of :class: SubmissionFileInfo

psef.files module¶

This module is used for file IO and handling and provides functions for extracting and abstracting the structures of directories and archives.

psef.files.create_csv(objects, attributes, headers=None)[source]¶

Create a csv file from the given objects and attributes.

Parameters:
  • objects (list of object) – The objects that will be listed
  • attributes (list of str) – The attributes of each object that will be listed
  • headers (list of str) – Column headers that will be the first row in the csv file
Returns:

The path to the csv file
Return type:

str
psef.files.create_csv_from_rows(rows)[source]¶

Create a csv file from the given rows.

Rows should be a nested list or other similar iterable like this: [[header_1, header_2], [row_1a, row_1b], [row_2a, row_2b]]

Parameters:rows (list of str) – The rows that will be used to populate the csv
Returns:The path to the csv file
Rtpe:str
psef.files.dehead_filetree(tree)[source]¶

Remove the head of the given filetree while preserving the old head name.

So a tree {1: 2: 3: 4: [f1, f2]} will be converted to {1: [f1, f2]}

Parameters:tree (dict) – The file tree as generated by extract().
Returns:The same tree but deheaded as described.
Return type:dict

Returns:Nothing
Rtype None:
psef.files.rename_directory_structure(rootdir)[source]¶

Creates a nested dictionary that represents the folder structure of rootdir.

A tree like:

  • dir1
    • dir 2
      • file 1
      • file 2
    • file 3

will be moved to files given by random_file_path() and the object returned will represent the file structure, which will be something like this:

{
    'dir1': {
        [
            'dir 2':{
                [
                    ('file 1', 'new_name'),
                    ('file 2', 'new_name2')
                ]
            },
            ('file 3', 'new_name3')
        ]
    }
}
Parameters:rootdir (str) – The root directory to rename, files will not be removed
Returns:The tree as described above
Return type:dict[str, dict[str, list[dict or tuple[str, str,]]]]
psef.files.restore_directory_structure(code, parent)[source]¶

Restores the directory structure recursively for a code submission (a models.Work).

The directory structure is returned like this:

{
    "id": 1,
    "name": "rootdir"
    "entries": [
        {
            "id": 2,
            "name": "file1.txt"
        },
        {
            "id": 3,
            "name": "subdir"
            "entries": [
                {
                    "id": 4,
                    "name": "file2.txt."
                },
                {
                    "id": 5,
                    "name": "file3.txt"
                }
            ],
        },
    ],
}
Parameters:
  • code (models.File) – A file
  • parent (str) – Path to parent directory
Returns:

A tree as described
Return type:

dict

default(obj)[source]¶

A way to serialize arbitrary methods to JSON.

Classes can use this method by implementing a __to_json__ method that should return a JSON serializable object.

Parameters:obj (object) – The object that should be converted to JSON.

psef.linters module¶

This module contains all the linters that are integrated in the service.

Integrated linters are ran by the LinterRunner and thus implement run method.

class psef.linters.BearLinter(config)[source]¶

Bases: psef.linters.Linter

Implements a generic coala linter.

This class itself is not a functional linter yet, you need to at least define/override NAME, DEFAULT_OPTIONS, FILTER_STR, EXTENSION and BEAR_NAME. The first two are defined in Linter, the third is the string passed to coala as files argument, the fourth is the extension that should be put after the LINTER_STR, and the last is the name of the bear that should be given to the coala program.

BEAR_NAME = None¶
EXTENSION = ‘*’¶
FILTER_STR = ‘/**/*.’¶
NAME = ‘__ignore__’¶
run(tempdir, emit)[source]¶

Run the bear linter.

The arguments are the same as for the base Linter.emit() function.

class psef.linters.ClangCheckBear(config)[source]¶

BEAR_NAME = ‘ClangBear’¶
DEFAULT_OPTIONS = {‘Empty config file’: ”}¶

class psef.linters.Linter(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

The base class for a linter.

Every linter should inherit from this class as they are discovered by reflecting on subclasses from this class. They should also override all methods and variables from this class.

DEFAULT_OPTIONS = {}¶
NAME = None¶
run(tempdir, emit)[source]¶

Run the bear linter on the code in tempdir.

Parameters:
  • tempdir (str) – The temp directory that should contain the code to run the linter on.
  • emit (Callable[str, str, str, str]) – A callback to emit a line of feedback, where the first argument is the filename, the second is the line number, the third is the code of the linter error, and the fourth and last is the message of the linter.
Return type:

None
class psef.linters.LinterRunner(cls, cfg)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class is used to run a Linter with a specific config on sets of models.Work.

linter¶
The attached :class:`Linter` that will be ran by this class.
run(works, tokens, urlpath)[source]¶

Run this linter runner on the given works.

Note

This method takes a long time to execute, please run it in a thread.

Note

The tokens and works should match item for item. So token[i] should be valid only for work[i].

The results will be send to the given URL with are PUT request and are identifiable by the token which will be formatted into the URL.

Parameters:
  • works (list[int]) – A list of ids of psef.models.Work items that will be fetched and where the linters will run on.
  • tokens (list[str]) – A list of tokens that are the ids of psef.models.LinterInstance that will be used when posting back to the given callback url.
  • urlpath (str) – The url that should be used to postback the result of the linters, it should be possible to do urlpath.format(token) which should result in a valid url for posting back the result.
Return type:

None
Returns:

Nothing
test(code, callback_url)[source]¶

Test the given code (models.Work) and send the results to the given URL.

Parameters:
  • code (psef.models.File) – The file that the linter should be run on, this file and all its children will be restored to a directory and the linter will run on them.
  • callback_url (str) – The url that should be used to give back the result of the linter.
Returns:

Nothing
Return type:

None

class psef.linters.Pylint(config)[source]¶

Bases: psef.linters.Linter

The pylint checker.

This checks python modules for many common errors. It only works on proper modules and will display an error on the first line of every file if the given code was not a proper module.

DEFAULT_OPTIONS = {‘Empty config file’: ”}¶

psef.linters.get_all_linters()[source]¶

Get an overview of all linters.

The returned linters are all the subclasses of Linter.

Returns:A mapping of the name of the linter to a dictionary containing the description and the default options of the linter with that name
Return type:dict
Example: 
>>> all_linters = get_all_linters()
>>> all_linters.keys()
dict_keys(['Pylint', 'Flake8'])
>>> all_linters['Flake8']
{'desc': 'The flake8 linter with all "noqa"s disabled.', 'opts':
    {'Empty config file': ''}}
psef.linters.get_linter_by_name(name)[source]¶

Get the linter class associated with the given name.

Parameters:name (str) – The name of the linter wanted.
Return type:Linter or None
Returns:The linter with the attribute NAME equal to name. If there are multiple linters with the name name the result can be any one of these linters. If no linter can be found None is returned

class psef.lti.LTI(req)[source]¶

Bases: object

The base LTI class.

course_id¶
course_name¶

The name of the current LTI course.

ensure_lti_user()[source]¶

Make sure the current LTI user is logged in as a psef user.

This is done by first checking if we know a user with the current LTI user_id, if this is the case this is the user we log in and return.

Otherwise we check if a user is logged in and this user has no LTI user_id, if this is the case we link the current LTI user_id to the current logged in user and return this user.

Otherwise we create a new user and link this user to current LTI user_id.

Return type:User
static generate_xml()[source]¶

Generate a config XML for this LTI consumer.

static passback_grade(secret, grade, service_url, sourcedid, text=None, url=None)[source]¶

Do a LTI grade passback.

Parameters:
  • key (str) – The oauth key to use.
  • secret (str) – The oauth secret to use.
  • grade (numbers.Rational) – The grade to pass back.
  • service_url (str) – The url used for grade passback.
  • sourcedid (str) – The sourcedid used in the grade passback.
  • text (None or str) – The text used as general feedback to the student.
  • url (None or str) – The url used as general feedback to the student which will probably be clickable.
Returns:

The response of the LTI consumer.
set_user_course_role(user, course)[source]¶

Set the course role for the given course and user if there is no such role just yet.

The mapping is done using LTI_ROLE_LOOKUPS

Parameters:
  • user (models.User) – The user to set the course role for.
  • course (models.Course) – The course to connect to user to.
Return type:

None
Returns:

Nothing
Raises:

ValueError – When the LTI role could not be converted.
set_user_role(user)[source]¶

Set the role of the given user if the user has no role.

The role is determined according to LTI_ROLE_LOOKUPS.

Note

If the role could not be matched the DEFAULT_ROLE configured in the config of the app is used.

Parameters:user (models.User) – The user to set the role for.
Returns:Nothing
Return type:None
user_email¶

The email of the current LTI user.

user_id¶

The unique id of the current LTI user.

user_name¶

The name or username of the current LTI user.

class psef.lti.OutcomeRequest(opts=defaultdict(<function OutcomeRequest.<lambda>>, {}))[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for consuming & generating LTI Outcome Requests.

Outcome Request documentation:
http://www.imsglobal.org/LTI/v1p1/ltiIMGv1p1.html#_Toc319560472

This class can be used both by Tool Providers and Tool Consumers, though they each use it differently. The TP will use it to POST an OAuth-signed request to the TC. A TC will use it to parse such a request from a TP.

static from_post_request()[source]¶

Convenience method for creating a new OutcomeRequest from a request object.

post_request is assumed to be a Django HttpRequest object

generate_request_xml()[source]¶
has_required_attributes()[source]¶
is_delete_request()[source]¶

Check whether this request is a deleteResult request.

is_read_request()[source]¶

Check whether this request is a readResult request.

is_replace_request()[source]¶

Check whether this request is a replaceResult request.

post_delete_result()[source]¶

POSTs a deleteRequest to the Tool Consumer.

post_outcome_request()[source]¶

POST an OAuth signed request to the Tool Consumer.

post_read_result()[source]¶

POSTS a readResult to the Tool Consumer.

post_replace_result(score, result_data=None)[source]¶

POSTs the given score to the Tool Consumer with a replaceResult.

OPTIONAL:
result_data must be a dictionary Note: ONLY ONE of these values can be in the dict at a time, due to the Canvas specification.
Parameters:
  • str – text: text
  • str – url: url
process_xml(xml)[source]¶

Parse Outcome Request data from XML.

was_outcome_post_successful()[source]¶
class psef.lti.OutcomeResponse(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class consumes & generates LTI Outcome Responses.

Response documentation:
http://www.imsglobal.org/LTI/v1p1/ltiIMGv1p1.html#_Toc319560472
Error code documentation:
http://www.imsglobal.org/gws/gwsv1p0/imsgws_baseProfv1p0.html#1639667

This class can be used by both Tool Providers and Tool Consumers, though each will use it differently. TPs will use it to partse the result of an OutcomeRequest to the TC. A TC will use it to generate proper response XML to send back to a TP.

static from_post_response(content)[source]¶

Convenience method for creating a new OutcomeResponse from a response object.

generate_response_xml()[source]¶

Generate XML based on the current configuration.

set_state(state)[source]¶

Update the current state (class:_AssignmentStateEnum).

You can update the state to hidden, done or open. A assignment can not be updated to ‘submitting’ or ‘grading’ as this is an assignment with state of ‘open’ and, respectively, a deadline before or after the current time.

Parameters:state (str) – The new state, can be ‘hidden’, ‘done’ or ‘open’
Returns:Nothing
Return type:None

class psef.models.AssignmentLinter(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: flask_sqlalchemy.Model

The class is used when a linter (see psef.linters) is used on a Assignment.

Every Work that is tested is attached by a LinterInstance.

The name identifies which linters.Linter is used.

class psef.models.File(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: flask_sqlalchemy.Model

This object describes a file or directory that stored is stored on the server.

Files are always connected to Work objects. A directory file does not physically exist but is stored only in the database to preserve the submitted work structure. Each submission should have a single top level file. Each other file in a submission should be directly or indirectly connected to this file via the parent attribute.

extension¶
filename¶
get_filename()[source]¶

Get the real filename of the file.

Returns:The filename of the file
Return type:str
id¶
is_directory¶
list_contents()[source]¶

List the basic file info and the info of its children.

If the file is a directory it will return a tree like this:

{
    'name': 'dir_1',
    'id': 1,
    'entries': [
        {
            'name': 'file_1',
            'id': 2
        },
        {
            'name': 'file_2',
            'id': 3
        },
        {
            'name': 'dir_2',
            'id': 4,
            'entries': []
        }
    ]
}

Otherwise it will formatted like one of the file children of the above tree.

Returns:A tree like above
Return type:dict
name¶
parent¶
parent_id¶
work¶
work_id¶

class psef.models.Permission(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: flask_sqlalchemy.Model

This class defines permissions by names that are checked in certain APIs.

A permission can be a global- or a course- permission. Global permissions describe the ability to do something general, e.g. create a course or the usage of snippets. These permissions are connected to a Role which is hold be a User. Similarly course permissions are bound to a CourseRole. These roles are assigned to users only in the context of a single Course. Thus a user can hold different permissions in different courses.

course_permission¶
default_value¶
id¶
name¶

get_all_permissions(course_id=None)[source]¶

Get all global permissions (Permission) of this user or all course permissions of the user in a specific Course.

Parameters:
  • permission (Permission or str) – The permission or permission name
  • course_id (None or Course or int) – The course or course id
Returns:

A name boolean mapping where the name is the name of the permission and the value indicates if this user has this permission.
Return type:

dict[str, bool]

Parameters:permission (Permission or str) – The permission or its name
Returns:An int bool mapping where the int is the course id and the the bool whether the user has the permission in the course with thid id

has_permission(permission, course_id=None)[source]¶

Check whether this user has the specified global or course Permission.

To check a course permission the course_id has to be set.

  • permission (Permission or str) – The permission or permission name
  • course_id (None or int or Course) – The course or course id
Returns:

Whether the role has the permission or not

bool
Raises:

KeyEror – If the permission parameter is a string and no permission with this name exists.
